[Verse 1]

We have three eight-measure verses with an A-A-B-B phrasing. The second and third one is sung an octave higher with incredible energy and funky strummed guitar chords added in contrast with the more economic first verse. The lead tune (in the second verse only) features a ♭5th, and the bass line also features some chromatic passing notes the last one (A) is copied by the lead vocal. The last measure adds a dissonant guitar chord (G-A#-C-F). The first verse ends with reversed cymbals and the second verse adds more weird noises. Except for the octave-up transposition, the lead tune is also changed. The third verse offers further variants of the lead melody, adding also single-part harmonies.
[Intro]

The song starts with the famous two-measure riff played five times, the first two times a variant with an upbeat. The riff uses only three different notes (E, G, A). For the third phase where the main version of the ostinato riff debuts enters the guitar doubling it. The last two phrases add a flanged synth chord (Em7) fading in and abruptly stopped. We then hear the first verse.

Another one bites the dust

The phrase is commonly attributed to the ending of many Wild West gun battles.

One of the “experts” in perpetuating this deed was Gary Cooper – here at “High Noon” he watches “another one bites the dust”.

Medical professionals teaching CPR (Cardio-Pulmonary resuscitation) use this song (along with the The Bee Gees' “Stayin' Alive”) to teach the desired rate for chest compression; the song’s tempo runs at the proper 110 beats per minute.

You can beat him, you can cheat him, you can treat him bad
 And leave him when he’s down, yeah

Although it can be used to describe the more anonymous scenario in the first verse, this list leans more towards the aggressive breakup idea of the song.

“Beating” could allude to domestic violence among the couple, or just a beating itself.

“Cheating” is less of the romantic cheating between other people and more sly corruption, maybe with money.

In general, the lovers or enemies could just treat each other bad and when one finally strikes the upper hand, he or she can leave them in the dust, either dead or broken.

There are plenty of ways you can hurt a man
 And bring him to the ground

By switching to third person, the song switches from a personal story (told in first and second person) to a general statement of any “man”.

Using the “bring him to the ground” expression, the lyricist creates a poetic way to explain how “he” will get closer to biting the (“ground’s”) dust.

Are you ready? Hey, are you ready for this?
 Are you hanging on the edge of your seat?

As in the pivotal scene of a Western, tension is really starting to build. Deacon uses rhetorical questions to build this tension. The lack of resolution builds anxiety and excitement as if watching the start of a duel.

The narrator is speaking to film audience, making them beg for the entertainment that they would experience with war scenes.

But I’m ready, yes I’m ready for you
 I’m standing on my own two feet

The narrator of the song is confident that he won’t be destroyed by his ex-lover and forced to bite the dust. He’s capable of flourishing on his own – that’s what the “standing on your own two feet” idiom means.
